lessons.title: Reading environment variables
lessons.description: Learn how to read environment variables using System.getenv() in Java
lessons.expectedOutput:
PATH exists: true
User: [username]
Total environment variables: [count]
lessons.tutorial:
Reading Environment Variables in Java

Environment variables are key-value pairs provided by the operating system that allow configuration without changing code.

Basic Usage

Read a single environment variable: 
String path = System.getenv("PATH");
if (path != null) {
    System.out.println("PATH: " + path);
} else {
    System.out.println("PATH not set");
}

Reading All Variables

Get all environment variables as a Map: 
Map env = System.getenv();
for (Map.Entry entry : env.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println(entry.getKey() + " = " + entry.getValue());
}

Cross-Platform Variable Names

Different operating systems use different variable names: 
// Get username (cross-platform)
String user = System.getenv("USER");  // Unix/Linux/Mac
if (user == null) {
    user = System.getenv("USERNAME");  // Windows
}
System.out.println("Current user: " + user);
// Get home directory
String home = System.getenv("HOME");  // Unix
if (home == null) {
    home = System.getenv("USERPROFILE");  // Windows
}

Common Environment Variables

  • PATH: Directories to search for executables
  • HOME (Unix) / USERPROFILE (Windows): User's home directory
  • USER (Unix) / USERNAME (Windows): Current username
  • JAVA_HOME: Java installation directory
  • TEMP / TMP: Temporary files directory

Best Practices

  • Always check for null: Variables may not be set
  • Handle platform differences: Use fallback logic for OS-specific variables
  • Don't rely on case: Variable names are case-sensitive on Unix, case-insensitive on Windows
  • Security: Never log sensitive environment variables (API keys, passwords)

When to Use

  • Reading system configuration
  • Detecting runtime environment
  • Finding system directories
  • Getting user information
  • CI/CD pipeline configuration

lessons.title: Default environment variable values
lessons.description: Learn how to provide default values for environment variables
lessons.expectedOutput:
App: MyApp
Port: 8080
Log Level: INFO
lessons.tutorial:
Default Environment Variable Values in Java

Providing default values makes your application more robust and easier to configure.

Reading with Defaults

The basic pattern for environment variables with defaults: 
private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
    String value = System.getenv(name);
    return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
}
// Usage
String appName = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
String port = getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080");

Type Conversion

Since environment variables are always strings, you need to convert them: 
// Integer
int port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
// Boolean
boolean debug = Boolean.parseBoolean(getEnvOrDefault("DEBUG", "false"));
// With error handling
int timeout;
try {
    timeout = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("TIMEOUT", "30"));
} catch (NumberFormatException e) {
    timeout = 30; // fallback default
}

Configuration Class Pattern

For complex applications, create a configuration class: 
public class AppConfig {
    public static final String APP_NAME = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
    public static final int PORT = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
    public static final String LOG_LEVEL = getEnvOrDefault("LOG_LEVEL", "INFO");
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

Best Practices

  • Document all variables: Maintain a README or .env.example file listing all expected environment variables
  • Use sensible defaults: Development-friendly defaults reduce configuration burden
  • Validate after parsing: Check that converted values are in acceptable ranges
  • Fail fast: For required variables without good defaults, fail early with clear error messages

When to Use

  • Configuring server ports, database URLs, API keys
  • Feature flags and debug modes
  • Environment-specific settings (dev/staging/prod)
  • Docker and cloud deployments

Example: Complete Configuration

public class DatabaseConfig {
    private final String host;
    private final int port;
    private final String database;
    public DatabaseConfig() {
        this.host = getEnvOrDefault("DB_HOST", "localhost");
        this.port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("DB_PORT", "5432"));
        this.database = getEnvOrDefault("DB_NAME", "myapp");
        validate();
    }
    private void validate() {
        if (port < 1 || port > 65535) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid port: " + port);
        }
    }
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

INFO: This is an INFO message
Check console for log messages
lessons.tutorial:
Java's logging framework provides a hierarchical system for tracking application behavior, debugging issues, and monitoring production systems. The java.util.logging package offers five primary logging levels (SEVERE, WARNING, INFO, CONFIG, FINE) that help developers categorize message importance. Understanding logging levels is crucial for effective debugging and system monitoring in enterprise applications where you need to track what's happening across distributed components.

Basic Pattern

import java.util.logging.;
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(MyClass.class.getName());
logger.severe("Critical error occurred");
logger.warning("Potential issue detected");
logger.info("Normal operation message");

Advanced Usage

import java.util.logging.;
public class LoggerDemo {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(LoggerDemo.class.getName());
    static {
        logger.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
        handler.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        logger.addHandler(handler);
        logger.setUseParentHandlers(false);
    }
    public void processData(String data) {
        logger.fine("Processing started: " + data);
        logger.config("Configuration loaded");
        logger.info("Data processed successfully");
    }
}

Complete Example

import java.util.logging.*;
public class Main {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            logger.info("Application started");
            int result = divide(10, 0);
            logger.info("Result: " + result);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.severe("Exception occurred: " + e.getMessage());
            logger.warning("Using default value");
        } finally {
            logger.info("Application shutdown");
        }
    }
    static int divide(int a, int b) {
        logger.fine("Dividing " + a + " by " + b);
        return a / b;
    }
}

Common Use Cases

  • Error tracking: Log exceptions and error conditions with SEVERE level for immediate attention
  • Debugging production issues: Use INFO and FINE levels to trace application flow without overwhelming logs
  • Performance monitoring: Track operation timing and resource usage with appropriate log levels
  • Audit trails: Record user actions and system events for compliance and security analysis

Best Practices

  • Use appropriate log levels consistently across your application (SEVERE for errors, WARNING for issues, INFO for milestones)
  • Include contextual information in log messages (user IDs, transaction IDs, timestamps)
  • Configure log levels externally via properties files rather than hard-coding in source
  • Avoid logging sensitive data (passwords, credit cards, personal information)
  • Use parameterized logging for better performance: logger.log(Level.INFO, "User {0} logged in", userId)

When to Use

Use Java logging when building production applications that require monitoring and debugging capabilities, when you need hierarchical logger control across modules, when compliance requires audit trails, or when you're working in enterprise environments with centralized logging systems. Logging is essential for diagnosing issues in deployed applications where debuggers aren't available.

lessons.title: Custom log formatter
lessons.description: Learn how to create custom log formatters in Java
lessons.expectedOutput:
[2024-01-15 10:30:45] INFO: Application started
[2024-01-15 10:30:45] WARNING: This is a warning
lessons.tutorial:
Custom log formatters in Java allow precise control over log output format, including timestamps, thread information, log levels, and message content. The java.util.logging.Formatter abstract class provides the foundation for creating formatters, with SimpleFormatter and XMLFormatter as built-in implementations. Creating custom formatters enables consistent logging across enterprise applications and integration with log aggregation systems like ELK stack or Splunk.

Basic Pattern

import java.util.logging.;
public class SimpleCustomFormatter extends Formatter {
    @Override
    public String format(LogRecord record) {
        return String.format("[%s] %s: %s%n",
            record.getLevel(),
            record.getLoggerName(),
            record.getMessage()
        );
    }
}
// Usage
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger("MyLogger");
ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
handler.setFormatter(new SimpleCustomFormatter());
logger.addHandler(handler);

Advanced Usage

import java.util.logging.;
import java.time.;
import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
public class DetailedFormatter extends Formatter {
    private static final DateTimeFormatter formatter =
        DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS");
    @Override
    public String format(LogRecord record) {
        LocalDateTime timestamp = LocalDateTime.ofInstant(
            Instant.ofEpochMilli(record.getMillis()),
            ZoneId.systemDefault()
        );
        return String.format("%s | %s | %s | %s.%s | %s%n",
            timestamp.format(formatter),
            Thread.currentThread().getName(),
            record.getLevel(),
            record.getSourceClassName(),
            record.getSourceMethodName(),
            record.getMessage()
        );
    }
}

Complete Example

import java.util.logging.;
import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.io.StringWriter;
public class Main {
    static class JsonFormatter extends Formatter {
        @Override
        public String format(LogRecord record) {
            StringBuilder json = new StringBuilder("{");
            json.append("\"timestamp\":").append(record.getMillis()).append(",");
            json.append("\"level\":\"").append(record.getLevel()).append("\",");
            json.append("\"logger\":\"").append(record.getLoggerName()).append("\",");
            json.append("\"message\":\"").append(escape(record.getMessage())).append("\"");
            if (record.getThrown() != null) {
                StringWriter sw = new StringWriter();
                record.getThrown().printStackTrace(new PrintWriter(sw));
                json.append(",\"exception\":\"").append(escape(sw.toString())).append("\"");
            }
            json.append("}\n");
            return json.toString();
        }
        private String escape(String str) {
            return str.replace("\\", "\\\\").replace("\"", "\\\"").replace("\n", "\\n");
        }
    }
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());
        ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
        handler.setFormatter(new JsonFormatter());
        logger.addHandler(handler);
        logger.setUseParentHandlers(false);
        logger.info("Application started");
        logger.warning("Low memory detected");
        try {
            throw new RuntimeException("Test exception");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.log(Level.SEVERE, "Error occurred", e);
        }
    }
}

Common Use Cases

  • JSON logging: Format logs as JSON for easy parsing by log aggregation tools like ELK stack
  • Structured logging: Include metadata fields (user ID, request ID, session ID) in consistent format
  • Console output: Create human-readable formats for development with color coding and alignment
  • Integration with monitoring: Format logs to match requirements of monitoring systems like Splunk or Datadog

Best Practices

  • Keep format() method thread-safe as it may be called concurrently from multiple threads
  • Cache expensive objects like DateTimeFormatter instances as class-level static fields
  • Include essential context (timestamp, level, logger name) in every formatted message
  • Escape special characters properly when generating JSON, XML, or CSV formatted logs
  • Consider performance impact of complex formatting; use buffered output for high-volume logging

When to Use

Use custom formatters when integrating with centralized logging infrastructure, when you need machine-parseable log formats (JSON, XML), when building microservices that require consistent log formats across services, or when existing formatters don't provide needed information. Custom formatters are essential for production systems with sophisticated monitoring and alerting requirements.

Common Use Cases

  • Production applications: Implement Strategy - Runtime Selection in enterprise applications for better maintainability
  • Code organization: Use Strategy - Runtime Selection to structure code more effectively and improve readability
  • Performance optimization: Apply Strategy - Runtime Selection to enhance application performance and resource usage
  • Best practices: Follow industry standards by properly implementing Strategy - Runtime Selection in your projects

Best Practices

When to Use

Use Strategy - Runtime Selection when building applications that require this specific functionality, when you need to improve code quality and maintainability, when working on enterprise projects with specific requirements, or when following architectural patterns that benefit from this approach. This is essential for creating professional, production-ready software.

lessons.title: Memento - State Capture and Restore
lessons.description: Implement Memento pattern to capture and restore object state without violating encapsulation.
lessons.tutorial:
This lesson covers Memento - State Capture and Restore in Java, an essential concept for building robust and maintainable applications. Understanding Memento - State Capture and Restore helps you write cleaner code, improve performance, and follow industry best practices. This pattern is widely used in enterprise Java development and is fundamental to creating scalable, production-ready software that can handle real-world requirements effectively.

Basic Pattern

// Basic implementation of Memento - State Capture and Restore
public class Example {
    public void demonstrate() {
        // Implementation here
        System.out.println("Demonstrating Memento - State Capture and Restore");
    }

Advanced Usage

// Advanced implementation with additional features
public class AdvancedExample {

    public AdvancedExample(String config) {
        this.config = config;

Complete Example

import java.util.*;

Common Use Cases

  • Production applications: Implement Memento - State Capture and Restore in enterprise applications for better maintainability
  • Code organization: Use Memento - State Capture and Restore to structure code more effectively and improve readability
  • Performance optimization: Apply Memento - State Capture and Restore to enhance application performance and resource usage

When to Use

Use Memento - State Capture and Restore when building applications that require this specific functionality, when you need to improve code quality and maintainability, when working on enterprise projects with specific requirements, or when following architectural patterns that benefit from this approach. This is essential for creating professional, production-ready software.

lessons.title: Composite Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Composite pattern to treat individual objects and compositions uniformly using tree structures.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Folder: root
  Folder: documents
    File: document.txt (100 KB)
    File: readme.md (50 KB)
  Folder: pictures
    File: image.png (500 KB)
lessons.tutorial:
The Composite pattern is a structural design pattern that lets you compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies. It allows clients to treat individual objects and compositions of objects uniformly.

Key Components:

  • Component: Interface for all objects in the composition (FileSystemComponent)
  • Leaf: Represents leaf objects with no children (File)
  • Composite: Stores child components and implements child-related operations (Folder)

Example Implementation:

interface FileSystemComponent {
    void display(int indent);
    int getSize();
}

class Folder implements FileSystemComponent {
    private List<FileSystemComponent> components = new ArrayList<>();

    public void add(FileSystemComponent component) {
        components.add(component);
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Representing part-whole hierarchies (file systems, UI components, organization charts)
  • Treating individual objects and compositions uniformly
  • Building tree structures where nodes can be leaves or composites

Best Practices:

  • Define a common interface for all components
  • Implement child management in composite classes only
  • Use recursion for tree traversal operations
  • Consider making components immutable when possible

Real-World Applications:

File systems (folders containing files and folders), GUI frameworks (containers with widgets), document structures (sections with paragraphs), and organizational hierarchies.

lessons.title: Interpreter Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Interpreter pattern to define a grammar and interpret sentences in a language.
lessons.tutorial:
The Interpreter pattern is a behavioral design pattern that defines a representation for a language's grammar along with an interpreter that uses the representation to interpret sentences in the language.

Key Components:

  • AbstractExpression: Interface declaring interpret operation (Expression)
  • TerminalExpression: Implements interpret for terminal symbols (NumberExpression)
  • NonterminalExpression: Implements interpret for non-terminal symbols (AddExpression, SubtractExpression)
  • Context: Contains information global to the interpreter

Example Implementation:

class AddExpression implements Expression {
    private Expression left, right;

    public int interpret() {
        return left.interpret() + right.interpret();
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Grammar is simple and not likely to change frequently
  • Efficiency is not a critical concern
  • Interpreting expressions, rules, or domain-specific languages
  • Building calculators, query parsers, or configuration interpreters

Best Practices:

  • Keep grammar simple to avoid class explosion
  • Use other patterns (Composite, Visitor) to extend functionality
  • Consider parser generators for complex grammars
  • Cache interpretation results when possible

Real-World Applications:

SQL parsers, regular expression engines, mathematical expression evaluators, configuration file parsers, and domain-specific language interpreters.

lessons.title: Iterator Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Iterator pattern to access elements of a collection sequentially without exposing its internal structure.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Books in collection:
1984 by George Orwell
To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee
The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald
lessons.tutorial:
The Iterator pattern is a behavioral design pattern that provides a way to access elements of a collection sequentially without exposing its underlying representation. It decouples collection traversal from the collection itself.

Key Components:

  • Iterator: Interface defining traversal operations (hasNext, next)
  • ConcreteIterator: Implements iterator interface and tracks position (BookIterator)
  • Aggregate: Interface for creating iterator
  • ConcreteAggregate: Implements aggregate interface (BookCollection)

Example Implementation:

interface Iterator<T> {
    boolean hasNext();
    T next();
}

class BookIterator implements Iterator<Book> {
    private int currentIndex = 0;

    public boolean hasNext() {
        return currentIndex < books.size();
    }

    public Book next() {
        return books.get(currentIndex++);
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Accessing collection elements without exposing internal structure
  • Supporting multiple simultaneous traversals
  • Providing uniform interface for traversing different collections
  • Implementing custom iteration logic

Best Practices:

  • Implement fail-fast behavior for concurrent modifications
  • Consider providing remove() operation when appropriate
  • Use Java's Iterable interface for enhanced for-loop support
  • Keep iterator state separate from collection state

Real-World Applications:

Java Collections Framework (List, Set iterators), database result sets, file system traversal, tree and graph traversal algorithms, and pagination systems.

lessons.title: Mediator Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Mediator pattern to reduce coupling between objects by centralizing complex communications.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Alice sends: Hello everyone!
Bob receives from Alice: Hello everyone!
Charlie receives from Alice: Hello everyone!
Bob sends: Hi Alice!
Alice receives from Bob: Hi Alice!
Charlie receives from Bob: Hi Alice!
Charlie sends: Hey there!
Alice receives from Charlie: Hey there!
Bob receives from Charlie: Hey there!
lessons.tutorial:
The Mediator pattern is a behavioral design pattern that reduces coupling between components by making them communicate indirectly through a special mediator object. It promotes loose coupling by keeping objects from referring to each other explicitly.

Key Components:

  • Mediator: Interface defining communication protocol (ChatMediator)
  • ConcreteMediator: Implements communication logic (ChatRoom)
  • Colleague: Objects that communicate through mediator (User)
  • Communication: All interactions go through mediator

Example Implementation:

class ChatRoom implements ChatMediator {
    private List<User> users = new ArrayList<>();

    public void sendMessage(String message, User sender) {
        for (User user : users) {
            if (user != sender) {
                user.receive(message, sender.getName());
            }
        }
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Objects communicate in complex but well-defined ways
  • Reusing objects is difficult due to many dependencies
  • Behavior distributed between classes should be customizable
  • Centralizing control logic in one place

Best Practices:

  • Keep mediator interface focused and cohesive
  • Avoid turning mediator into a "god object"
  • Use events or message passing for loose coupling
  • Consider combining with Observer pattern

Real-World Applications:

Chat applications, air traffic control systems, GUI dialog boxes with interdependent widgets, workflow engines, and event bus implementations.

lessons.title: Visitor Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Visitor pattern to add new operations to objects without modifying their classes.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Circle area: 78.53981633974483
Circle perimeter: 31.41592653589793
Rectangle area: 24.0
Rectangle perimeter: 20.0
lessons.tutorial:
The Visitor pattern is a behavioral design pattern that lets you separate algorithms from the objects on which they operate. It allows adding new operations to existing object structures without modifying them.

Key Components:

  • Visitor: Interface declaring visit methods for each element type (ShapeVisitor)
  • ConcreteVisitor: Implements operations for each element type (AreaCalculator)
  • Element: Interface with accept method (Shape)
  • ConcreteElement: Implements accept to call visitor (Circle, Rectangle)

Example Implementation:

interface ShapeVisitor {
    double visit(Circle circle);
    double visit(Rectangle rectangle);
}

class Circle implements Shape {
    public double accept(ShapeVisitor visitor) {
        return visitor.visit(this);
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Adding many unrelated operations across class hierarchy
  • Object structure is stable but operations change frequently
  • Keeping related operations together in one class
  • Avoiding pollution of domain classes with utility methods

Best Practices:

  • Use when object structure is stable
  • Consider double dispatch mechanism carefully
  • Group related operations in single visitor
  • Be aware that adding new element types requires updating all visitors

Real-World Applications:

Compiler AST traversal, document object models, tax calculations on different product types, serialization frameworks, and report generation systems.

lessons.title: Flyweight Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Flyweight pattern to minimize memory usage by sharing common data among similar objects.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Creating new Character object for: A
Creating new Character object for: B
a1 and a2 are same instance: true
Character: A at (10, 20) in red
Character: A at (15, 25) in blue
Character: B at (20, 30) in green
Total character objects created: 2
lessons.tutorial:
The Flyweight pattern is a structural design pattern that minimizes memory usage by sharing as much data as possible with similar objects. It's particularly useful when dealing with large numbers of similar objects.

Key Concepts:

  • Intrinsic State: Shared state stored in flyweight (char value)
  • Extrinsic State: Context-dependent state passed to flyweight (position, color)
  • Factory: Manages flyweight pool and ensures sharing (CharacterFactory)
  • Immutability: Flyweights should be immutable to enable safe sharing

Example Implementation:

class CharacterFactory {
    private Map<Character, Character> pool = new HashMap<>();

    public Character getCharacter(char value) {
        return pool.computeIfAbsent(value, Character::new);
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Application uses large number of similar objects
  • Storage costs are high due to object quantity
  • Most object state can be made extrinsic
  • Objects can be replaced by fewer shared objects

Best Practices:

  • Make flyweight objects immutable
  • Use factory to manage flyweight pool
  • Separate intrinsic and extrinsic state clearly
  • Consider using weak references for cache management

Real-World Applications:

Text editors (character rendering), game engines (particle systems, tiles), UI frameworks (glyph caching), and connection pooling systems.

lessons.title: Bridge Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Bridge pattern to decouple abstraction from implementation so they can vary independently.
lessons.expectedOutput:
TV is now ON
TV volume set to 40%
TV volume set to 50%

Radio is now ON
Radio volume set to 60%
Radio volume set to 0%
Device muted
lessons.tutorial:
The Bridge pattern is a structural design pattern that decouples an abstraction from its implementation so that the two can vary independently. It uses composition over inheritance to achieve this flexibility.

Key Components:

  • Abstraction: Defines high-level control logic (RemoteControl)
  • Implementation: Defines low-level operations interface (Device)
  • Refined Abstraction: Extends abstraction (BasicRemote, AdvancedRemote)
  • Concrete Implementation: Implements low-level operations (TV, Radio)

Example Implementation:

abstract class RemoteControl {
    protected Device device;

    public RemoteControl(Device device) {
        this.device = device;
    }

    public void togglePower() {
        if (device.isEnabled()) {
            device.disable();
        } else {
            device.enable();
        }
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Avoiding permanent binding between abstraction and implementation
  • Both abstractions and implementations should be extensible
  • Changes in implementation shouldn't affect clients
  • Sharing implementation among multiple objects

Best Practices:

  • Use composition to link abstraction and implementation
  • Define implementation interface independently of abstraction
  • Consider using dependency injection for implementation
  • Combine with Abstract Factory for creating bridges

Real-World Applications:

Device drivers, GUI frameworks (separating window from platform), database drivers, graphics rendering (separating shapes from drawing APIs), and cross-platform applications.

lessons.title: Web Scraping Basics
lessons.description: Learn HTML parsing and data extraction using string manipulation techniques.
lessons.tutorial:
Web scraping extracts data from HTML by parsing text content. While production systems use libraries like JSoup, understanding basic parsing helps you grasp underlying principles.

Key Concepts:

  • HTML Structure: Tags with opening and closing markers
  • String Parsing: Finding patterns using indexOf and substring
  • Data Extraction: Getting content between tags
  • Attribute Extraction: Finding href, src, and other attributes

Example Implementation:

public String getTitle() {
    int start = html.indexOf("<title>") + 7;
    int end = html.indexOf("</title>");
    return html.substring(start, end);
}

When to Use:

  • Extracting data from websites without APIs
  • Monitoring content or price changes
  • Aggregating information from multiple sources
  • Building search indexes or data analysis tools

Best Practices:

  • Respect robots.txt and website terms of service
  • Use robust parsing libraries in production (JSoup, HTMLUnit)
  • Implement rate limiting to avoid server overload
  • Handle malformed HTML gracefully
  • Cache results when appropriate

Real-World Applications:

Price comparison websites, content aggregators, SEO tools, market research platforms, and testing automation. Production systems typically use JSoup (Java) or Beautiful Soup (Python) for robust HTML parsing.

lessons.title: REST API Design
lessons.description: Learn RESTful API design principles with HTTP methods and resource modeling.
lessons.expectedOutput:
POST /users - 201 Created
GET /users/1 - 200 OK
PUT /users/1 - 200 OK
DELETE /users/1 - 204 No Content
lessons.tutorial:
REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for APIs using HTTP methods for CRUD operations on resources. RESTful design creates predictable, scalable web services.

Key Concepts:

  • Resources: Everything is a resource with a URI
  • HTTP Methods: GET (read), POST (create), PUT (update), DELETE (delete)
  • Stateless: Each request is independent
  • Status Codes: 200 OK, 201 Created, 404 Not Found, etc.

Example Implementation:

GET    /users     - List all\nGET    /users/:id - Get one\nPOST   /users     - Create\nPUT    /users/:id - Update\nDELETE /users/:id - Delete

When to Use:

  • Building web services and APIs
  • Creating scalable distributed systems
  • Supporting multiple client types
  • Third-party integrations

Best Practices:

  • Use plural nouns for resources (/users not /user)
  • Return proper HTTP status codes
  • Version your API (/v1/users)
  • Implement pagination for lists
  • Document with OpenAPI/Swagger

Real-World Applications:

Modern web applications, microservices, mobile app backends, third-party integrations. Frameworks: Spring Boot, Express.js, Django REST Framework, FastAPI.

lessons.title: GraphQL Basics
lessons.description: Learn GraphQL query language for flexible API data fetching.
lessons.tutorial:
GraphQL is a query language for APIs that lets clients request exactly the data they need. Unlike REST, clients specify the structure of the response.

Key Concepts:

  • Schema: Type system defining available data
  • Queries: Read operations with specific fields
  • Mutations: Write operations
  • Single Endpoint: One URL for all operations

Example Implementation:

query {\n  user(id: 1) {\n    name\n    email\n  }\n}

When to Use:

  • Avoiding over-fetching or under-fetching data
  • Flexible client requirements
  • Mobile applications with bandwidth constraints
  • Aggregating data from multiple sources

Best Practices:

  • Design clear schema with strong types
  • Implement pagination for lists
  • Use DataLoader to prevent N+1 queries
  • Version schema carefully
  • Monitor query complexity

Real-World Applications:

Modern web and mobile apps, API gateways, microservices aggregation. Used by Facebook, GitHub, Shopify. Libraries: GraphQL Java, Graphene (Python), Apollo.

lessons.title: Microservices Patterns
lessons.description: Learn microservices architecture patterns for building distributed systems.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Registered: user-service at localhost:8001
Registered: order-service at localhost:8002
User service at: localhost:8001
lessons.tutorial:
Microservices architecture decomposes applications into small, independent services that communicate over networks. Each service owns its data and can be deployed independently.

Key Concepts:

  • Service Discovery: Finding service locations dynamically
  • API Gateway: Single entry point for clients
  • Circuit Breaker: Preventing cascading failures
  • Saga Pattern: Distributed transactions

Example Implementation:

class ServiceRegistry {\n    Map<String, String> services;\n    \n    void register(String name, String addr) {\n        services.put(name, addr);\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Building large-scale distributed systems
  • Need independent deployment and scaling
  • Different technologies for different services
  • Team autonomy and parallel development

Best Practices:

  • Keep services small and focused
  • Use API gateways for routing
  • Implement circuit breakers and retries
  • Use message queues for async communication
  • Monitor and log distributed traces

Real-World Applications:

Netflix, Amazon, Uber use microservices for scalability. Common tools: Spring Cloud, Kubernetes, Istio, Consul for service mesh and discovery.

lessons.title: Message Queues
lessons.description: Learn asynchronous messaging patterns using message queues for decoupling services.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Sent: Task 1
Sent: Task 2
Received: Task 1
Received: Task 2
lessons.tutorial:
Message queues enable asynchronous communication between services by storing messages until consumers process them. This decouples producers from consumers and enables scalability.

Key Concepts:

  • Producer: Sends messages to queue
  • Consumer: Receives and processes messages
  • Queue: FIFO buffer storing messages
  • Pub/Sub: Multiple consumers for same message

Example Implementation:

class MessageQueue {\n    Queue<String> queue = new LinkedList<>();\n    \n    void send(String msg) {\n        queue.offer(msg);\n    }\n    \n    String receive() {\n        return queue.poll();\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Decoupling microservices
  • Handling traffic spikes with buffering
  • Async processing of long-running tasks
  • Event-driven architectures

Best Practices:

  • Use acknowledgments for reliability
  • Implement dead letter queues for failed messages
  • Set message TTL to prevent stale data
  • Monitor queue depth and latency
  • Use persistent queues for critical data

Real-World Applications:

E-commerce order processing, email sending, image processing, log aggregation. Technologies: RabbitMQ, Apache Kafka, Amazon SQS, Azure Service Bus.

lessons.title: Event Sourcing
lessons.description: Learn event sourcing pattern to store state as sequence of events.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Event stored: AccountCreated
Event stored: MoneyDeposited
Event stored: MoneyWithdrawn
Balance: 70
lessons.tutorial:
Event Sourcing stores all changes to application state as a sequence of events. Instead of storing current state, you store all events that led to that state, enabling time travel and audit trails.

Key Concepts:

  • Events: Immutable facts about what happened
  • Event Store: Append-only log of events
  • Replay: Rebuild state by applying events
  • Snapshots: Periodic state saves for performance

Example Implementation:

class EventStore {\n    List<Event> events = new ArrayList<>();\n    \n    void append(Event e) {\n        events.add(e);\n    }\n    \n    Account rebuild(String id) {\n        Account acc = new Account();\n        events.stream()\n            .filter(e -> e.getId().equals(id))\n            .forEach(acc::apply);\n        return acc;\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Need complete audit trail of changes
  • Temporal queries (state at any point in time)
  • Event-driven architectures
  • Complex business domains requiring history

Best Practices:

  • Make events immutable and self-describing
  • Use snapshots for performance with many events
  • Version event schemas carefully
  • Separate event store from read models
  • Handle event versioning and migration

Real-World Applications:

Financial systems, banking, inventory management, version control systems. Frameworks: Axon Framework, EventStore, Apache Kafka for event streaming.

lessons.title: CQRS Pattern
lessons.description: Learn Command Query Responsibility Segregation to separate read and write models.
lessons.expectedOutput:
User created: Alice
User created: Bob
Total users: 2
lessons.tutorial:
CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) separates read and write operations into different models. Commands change state, queries return data, enabling independent optimization of each.

Key Concepts:

  • Commands: Operations that change state (no return value)
  • Queries: Operations that return data (no state change)
  • Write Model: Optimized for updates and validation
  • Read Model: Optimized for queries and reporting

Example Implementation:

interface Command {}\ninterface Query<T> {}\n\nclass CQRS {\n    WriteModel writeModel;\n    ReadModel readModel;\n    \n    void execute(Command cmd) {\n        writeModel.handle(cmd);\n        readModel.update(cmd);\n    }\n    \n    <T> T query(Query<T> q) {\n        return readModel.fetch(q);\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Different scalability needs for reads vs writes
  • Complex business logic in write operations
  • Multiple read representations needed
  • Performance optimization for queries

Best Practices:

  • Keep commands and queries strictly separated
  • Use event sourcing with CQRS for consistency
  • Eventual consistency is often acceptable for reads
  • Denormalize read models for performance
  • Version commands carefully

Real-World Applications:

High-traffic applications, e-commerce platforms, financial systems. Often combined with Event Sourcing. Frameworks: Axon, MediatR, NServiceBus.

lessons.title: Hexagonal Architecture
lessons.description: Learn hexagonal architecture (ports and adapters) for decoupling business logic.
lessons.expectedOutput:
User created: Alice
User created: Bob
User exists: true
lessons.tutorial:
Hexagonal Architecture (Ports and Adapters) isolates business logic from external concerns. The domain is at the center, surrounded by ports (interfaces) and adapters (implementations) for external systems.

Key Concepts:

  • Domain Core: Business logic without external dependencies
  • Ports: Interfaces defining boundaries
  • Adapters: Implementations connecting to external systems
  • Dependency Inversion: Domain doesn't depend on infrastructure

Example Implementation:

// Port\ninterface UserRepository {\n    void save(User user);\n}\n\n// Domain\nclass UserService {\n    private UserRepository repo;\n    \n    UserService(UserRepository repo) {\n        this.repo = repo;\n    }\n}\n\n// Adapter\nclass DbUserRepository implements UserRepository {\n    public void save(User user) {\n        // DB logic\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Isolating business logic from frameworks
  • Supporting multiple UI or storage backends
  • Improving testability with mock adapters
  • Long-lived applications requiring flexibility

Best Practices:

  • Keep domain logic framework-agnostic
  • Define clear port interfaces
  • Use dependency injection for adapters
  • Test domain with mock adapters
  • Separate inbound and outbound ports

Real-World Applications:

Enterprise applications, microservices, domain-driven design implementations. Enables switching databases, UIs, or frameworks without changing business logic.

lessons.title: Repository Pattern
lessons.description: Learn the Repository pattern to abstract data access logic and provide collection-like interface.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Added user: Alice
Added user: Bob
Found: Alice
All users: 2
lessons.tutorial:
The Repository pattern mediates between domain and data mapping layers, providing a collection-like interface for accessing domain objects. It encapsulates storage, retrieval, and search logic.

Key Concepts:

  • Abstraction: Hides data access details from domain
  • Collection Interface: Add, find, remove like in-memory collection
  • Query Methods: findById, findAll, findByName, etc.
  • Persistence Agnostic: Domain doesn't know about database

Example Implementation:

class UserRepository {\n    private Map<Integer, User> storage;\n    \n    void add(User user) {\n        storage.put(user.getId(), user);\n    }\n    \n    User findById(int id) {\n        return storage.get(id);\n    }\n    \n    List<User> findAll() {\n        return new ArrayList<>(storage.values());\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Separating business logic from data access
  • Supporting multiple data sources
  • Centralizing data access logic
  • Improving testability with mock repositories

Best Practices:

  • Keep repositories focused on single aggregate
  • Return domain objects, not DTOs
  • Use specification pattern for complex queries
  • Don't expose IQueryable/ORM types to domain
  • One repository per aggregate root

Real-World Applications:

Domain-driven design applications, enterprise systems, layered architectures. Common with ORMs like Hibernate, Entity Framework, but repositories abstract the ORM.

lessons.title: Unit of Work Pattern
lessons.description: Learn Unit of Work pattern to maintain list of affected objects and coordinate transaction writes.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Registered new: Alice
Registered new: Bob
Registered dirty: Alice Updated

Committing transaction:
  INSERT Alice
  INSERT Bob
  UPDATE Alice Updated
Transaction committed!
lessons.tutorial:
The Unit of Work pattern maintains a list of objects affected by a business transaction and coordinates writing changes and resolving concurrency issues. It batches database operations for efficiency.

Key Concepts:

  • Change Tracking: Monitors new, modified, deleted objects
  • Transaction Management: Coordinates atomic commits
  • Batching: Groups multiple operations into single transaction
  • Identity Map: Ensures one instance per database row

Example Implementation:

class UnitOfWork {\n    List<Object> newObjects;\n    List<Object> dirtyObjects;\n    \n    void registerNew(Object obj) {\n        newObjects.add(obj);\n    }\n    \n    void commit() {\n        insertNew();\n        updateDirty();\n        deleteRemoved();\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Managing complex transactions with multiple objects
  • Batching database operations for performance
  • Ensuring transactional consistency
  • Working with ORMs like Hibernate or Entity Framework

Best Practices:

  • Commit at end of business transaction
  • Track changes automatically where possible
  • Handle concurrency conflicts appropriately
  • Clear unit of work after commit
  • Use with Repository pattern

Real-World Applications:

Built into most ORMs (Hibernate Session, EF DbContext). Essential for complex business transactions in enterprise applications requiring ACID guarantees.

lessons.title: Specification Pattern
lessons.description: Encapsulate business rules as reusable, combinable specifications.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Is adult: true
Is premium adult: true
lessons.tutorial:
The Specification pattern encapsulates business rules as reusable objects that can be combined using logical operators. It separates query logic from domain entities.

Key Concepts:

  • Specification: Encapsulates a business rule
  • Composite: Combine specs with AND, OR, NOT
  • Reusability: Share specifications across queries
  • Expressiveness: Read like business requirements

Example Implementation:

class AgeSpecification {
    int minAge;
    
    boolean isSatisfiedBy(User user) {
        return user.age >= minAge;
    }
}

When to Use:

  • Complex business rule validation
  • Building dynamic queries
  • Filtering collections
  • Reusing business logic across layers

Best Practices:

  • Keep specifications focused on single rule
  • Use composite pattern for combinations
  • Make specifications immutable
  • Name specs after business concepts

Real-World Applications:

E-commerce product filtering, insurance eligibility checks, access control rules. Common in DDD applications for encapsulating domain logic.

lessons.title: Value Objects
lessons.description: Create immutable domain primitives with value-based equality.
lessons.tutorial:
Value Objects are immutable domain primitives identified by their values, not identity. They represent descriptive aspects of the domain with no conceptual identity.

Key Concepts:

  • Value Equality: Compared by values, not reference
  • Immutability: Cannot be modified after creation
  • No Identity: Two objects with same values are interchangeable
  • Side-Effect Free: Operations return new instances

Example Implementation:

class Money {\n    private final int amount;\n    private final String currency;\n    \n    public Money add(Money other) {\n        return new Money(amount + other.amount, currency);\n    }\n    \n    public boolean equals(Object obj) {\n        // Compare by value\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Representing money, dates, addresses
  • Domain concepts without identity
  • Method parameters and return values
  • Avoiding primitive obsession

Best Practices:

  • Make value objects immutable
  • Override equals() and hashCode()
  • Validate in constructor
  • Operations return new instances
  • Use final fields (Java) or frozen dataclasses (Python)

Real-World Applications:

Money, coordinates, date ranges, email addresses, phone numbers in domain models. Essential in DDD for rich domain modeling instead of using primitives.

lessons.title: Aggregates
lessons.description: Define consistency boundaries and transactional boundaries in domain models.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Added: Item1
Added: Item2
Total: 150
Items: 2
lessons.tutorial:
Aggregates are clusters of domain objects treated as a single unit with a root entity that controls access. They enforce invariants and define transactional boundaries.

Key Concepts:

  • Aggregate Root: Single entry point for external access
  • Consistency Boundary: Invariants enforced within aggregate
  • Transaction Boundary: Saved/loaded as atomic unit
  • Identity: Referenced from outside by root's ID only

Example Implementation:

class Order {  // Aggregate Root\n    private List<OrderItem> items;\n    \n    public void addItem(OrderItem item) {\n        // Enforce business rules\n        items.add(item);\n    }\n    \n    // No direct access to items from outside\n}

When to Use:

  • Enforcing business invariants
  • Defining transaction boundaries
  • Modeling complex domain entities
  • Ensuring consistency in distributed systems

Best Practices:

  • Keep aggregates small
  • Reference other aggregates by ID only
  • Use repository per aggregate root
  • Enforce invariants in aggregate methods
  • One transaction per aggregate

Real-World Applications:

E-commerce orders with items, banking accounts with transactions, project management with tasks. Core to DDD for maintaining consistency.

lessons.title: Domain Events
lessons.description: Capture and notify when significant changes occur in the domain.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Event: OrderCreated
Handler: Order ORD-1 created
Event: OrderShipped
lessons.tutorial:
Domain Events represent something significant that happened in the domain. They enable loose coupling between aggregates and trigger side effects.

Key Concepts:

  • Event: Immutable record of something that happened
  • Publisher: Aggregate publishes events when state changes
  • Subscriber: Handlers react to events
  • Async Processing: Events enable eventual consistency

Example Implementation:

class OrderCreated extends DomainEvent {\n    String orderId;\n    Instant timestamp;\n}\n\nclass EventBus {\n    void publish(DomainEvent event) {\n        notifySubscribers(event);\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Decoupling aggregates and bounded contexts
  • Triggering side effects (emails, notifications)
  • Event sourcing and audit trails
  • Integrating with external systems

Best Practices:

  • Name events in past tense (OrderCreated not CreateOrder)
  • Include relevant data in event
  • Make events immutable
  • Publish events after transaction commits
  • Handle events idempotently

Real-World Applications:

E-commerce (OrderPlaced triggers inventory, shipping), banking (TransferCompleted triggers notifications), CRM (CustomerRegistered triggers welcome email).

lessons.title: DTOs
lessons.description: Transfer data between layers without exposing domain internals.
lessons.tutorial:
Data Transfer Objects are simple objects that carry data between processes or layers. They contain no business logic and protect domain models from external exposure.

Key Concepts:

  • Data Container: Only properties, no behavior
  • Serialization: Easy to serialize for APIs
  • Decoupling: API shape independent of domain model
  • Security: Don't expose sensitive domain fields

Example Implementation:

class UserDTO {\n    public int id;\n    public String name;\n    // No password field\n    \n    static UserDTO fromDomain(User user) {\n        return new UserDTO(user.id, user.name);\n    }\n}

When to Use:

  • Transferring data between layers (API to domain)
  • Protecting domain model from external changes
  • Optimizing data transfer (fewer fields)
  • API versioning

Best Practices:

  • Keep DTOs simple with no logic
  • Map explicitly between domain and DTO
  • Don't reuse DTOs across different APIs
  • Use tools like MapStruct or AutoMapper
  • Version DTOs separately from domain

Real-World Applications:

REST APIs, microservices communication, UI layer data binding. Prevents exposing domain internals and allows independent evolution.

lessons.title: API Versioning
lessons.description: Manage multiple API versions to support backward compatibility.
lessons.tutorial:
API versioning allows evolving APIs while maintaining backward compatibility for existing clients. Different versions can coexist, giving clients time to migrate.

Key Concepts:

  • URL Versioning: /v1/users, /v2/users
  • Header Versioning: Accept: application/vnd.api+json;version=2
  • Query Parameter: /users?version=2
  • Semantic Versioning: Major.Minor.Patch

Example Implementation:

// URL Versioning\n@GetMapping("/v1/users/{id}")\npublic UserV1 getUserV1(@PathVariable int id) {\n    return service.getUserV1(id);\n}\n\n@GetMapping("/v2/users/{id}")\npublic UserV2 getUserV2(@PathVariable int id) {\n    return service.getUserV2(id);\n}

When to Use:

  • Breaking changes to public APIs
  • Supporting multiple client versions
  • Gradual migration strategies
  • Long-lived APIs with many consumers

Best Practices:

  • Use semantic versioning
  • Version only when breaking changes occur
  • Deprecate old versions gracefully with warnings
  • Document version differences clearly
  • Set sunset dates for old versions

Real-World Applications:

Public APIs, microservices, mobile app backends. Companies like Stripe, Twilio version APIs extensively. Common in REST APIs.

lessons.title: Pagination
lessons.description: Handle large result sets efficiently by returning data in pages.
lessons.tutorial:
Pagination divides large result sets into smaller pages for better performance and user experience. It reduces memory usage and network transfer.

Key Concepts:

  • Page Number: Which page to return (1-based)
  • Page Size: Items per page (e.g., 20)
  • Total Count: Total items available
  • Cursor-Based: Alternative using cursors instead of page numbers

Example Implementation:

class Page<T> {\n    List<T> items;\n    int pageNumber;\n    int pageSize;\n    int totalCount;\n    int totalPages;\n}\n\npublic Page<User> getUsers(int page, int size) {\n    int offset = (page - 1) * size;\n    List<User> items = db.query(\"SELECT * FROM users LIMIT ? OFFSET ?\", size, offset);\n    return new Page(items, page, size, getTotalCount());\n}

When to Use:

  • Large datasets in APIs
  • Database query results
  • Search results
  • Infinite scrolling in UIs

Best Practices:

  • Include total count for UI (page X of Y)
  • Use cursor-based pagination for real-time data
  • Validate page number and size parameters
  • Set maximum page size to prevent abuse
  • Return links to next/prev pages (HATEOAS)

Real-World Applications:

REST APIs, database queries, search engines, social media feeds. Essential for scalability with large datasets.

lessons.title: Search and Filtering
lessons.description: Implement flexible search and filtering capabilities for querying data.
lessons.tutorial:
Search and filtering enables users to find specific data by applying criteria. Good search UX is critical for applications with large datasets.

Key Concepts:

  • Full-Text Search: Search across text fields
  • Faceted Search: Multiple filter dimensions (category, price, etc.)
  • Range Filters: Min/max values for numeric fields
  • Sorting: Order results by relevance or field values

Example Implementation:

public List<Product> search(SearchCriteria criteria) {\n    return products.stream()\n        .filter(p -> matchesCategory(p, criteria.category))\n        .filter(p -> matchesPriceRange(p, criteria.minPrice, criteria.maxPrice))\n        .filter(p -> matchesKeyword(p, criteria.keyword))\n        .sorted(criteria.sortBy)\n        .collect(Collectors.toList());\n}

When to Use:

  • E-commerce product catalogs
  • Document management systems
  • Admin dashboards
  • Any application with large datasets

Best Practices:

  • Support multiple filter combinations
  • Use indexes for performance
  • Implement autocomplete for better UX
  • Show filter counts (100 Electronics, 50 Furniture)
  • Allow saving search queries

Real-World Applications:

E-commerce sites (Amazon, eBay filtering), job boards, real estate listings, document search. Often uses Elasticsearch or Solr for advanced search.

lessons.title: AWS S3 - File Upload and Storage
lessons.description: Learn to upload and manage files in AWS S3 cloud storage using simulated API calls.
lessons.expectedOutput:
PUT s3://my-bucket/documents/report.pdf
File uploaded successfully
Bucket contents:
  - documents/report.pdf
Retrieved: File content here
lessons.tutorial:
AWS S3 (Simple Storage Service) is an object storage service offering industry-leading scalability, data availability, security, and performance. It's used by companies worldwide to store and retrieve any amount of data.

Key Concepts:

  • Buckets: Containers for storing objects (files)
  • Objects: Files stored in buckets with unique keys
  • Keys: Unique identifiers for objects (like file paths)
  • Regions: Geographic locations where buckets are created
  • Storage Classes: Different tiers (Standard, Infrequent Access, Glacier)

Example Implementation:

// AWS SDK usage (real implementation)\nimport software.amazon.awssdk.services.s3.S3Client;\nimport software.amazon.awssdk.services.s3.model.*;\n\nS3Client s3 = S3Client.builder()\n    .region(Region.US_EAST_1)\n    .build();\n\n// Upload\nPutObjectRequest request = PutObjectRequest.builder()\n    .bucket("my-bucket")\n    .key("file.txt")\n    .build();\ns3.putObject(request, RequestBody.fromString("content"));

When to Use:

  • Storing user uploads (images, documents, videos)
  • Hosting static website files
  • Backup and archiving data
  • Data lakes and big data analytics
  • Content delivery and media streaming

Best Practices:

  • Use descriptive key names with prefixes (folders)
  • Enable versioning for important data
  • Set appropriate IAM policies for access control
  • Use lifecycle policies to transition old data to cheaper storage
  • Enable server-side encryption for sensitive data
  • Use CloudFront CDN for faster global access

Real-World Applications:

Used by Netflix for video storage, Airbnb for property images, Dropbox for file storage, and millions of websites for static asset hosting. Essential skill for cloud engineers working with AWS.

lessons.title: AWS S3 - Signed URLs and Presigned URLs

Presigned URLs provide temporary access to S3 without AWS credentials. Used by Dropbox, Slack for direct uploads.

Best Practices:

  • Short expiration times
  • Generate on-demand
  • Validate client-side
  • Add metadata
  • Rate limiting

Production Considerations:

  • Monitor performance metrics and set up alerts for anomalies
  • Implement proper error handling and logging for debugging
  • Use environment variables for configuration management
  • Set up automated testing in CI/CD pipeline
  • Document architecture decisions and API contracts
  • Plan for disaster recovery and backup strategies

Common Pitfalls to Avoid:

  • Not implementing proper authentication and authorization
  • Ignoring rate limiting and causing service overload
  • Hard-coding configuration instead of using environment variables
  • Skipping error handling for edge cases
  • Not monitoring resource usage in production
  • Forgetting to implement retry logic for transient failures

Career Relevance:

This skill is essential for senior engineer roles at top tech companies. Understanding these concepts demonstrates production-ready knowledge and architectural thinking that hiring managers look for. Companies like Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Netflix, and Uber rely heavily on these patterns in their infrastructure.

Real-World Applications:

Dropbox for sharing, Slack for attachments, Zoom for recordings. Essential for scalable uploads.

lessons.title: Design URL Shortener (Bit.ly)
lessons.description: Design a scalable URL shortening service with Base62 encoding, collision handling, and caching strategy
lessons.expectedOutput:
Short: G8
Long: https://www.google.com
Short: G9
Duplicate: true
lessons.tutorial:
System Design: URL Shortener (Bit.ly)

Problem Overview

Design a service like Bit.ly that converts long URLs into short, shareable links. Must handle 100M URLs/day with <100ms latency and 10:1 read/write ratio.

Key Requirements

  • Functional: Shorten URL, retrieve original, handle duplicates
  • Non-Functional: High availability (99.99%), low latency (<100ms), scalable (100M/day)
  • Scale Estimation: 100M URLs/day 365 days 5 years = 183B URLs total
  • Storage: 500 bytes per URL 183B = 91 TB over 5 years

Algorithm: Base62 Encoding

Why Base62? (0-9, a-z, A-Z)
- URL-safe characters only
- 62^7 = 3.5 trillion unique combinations
- Shorter than Base10 or Base16

Example: 1000 in Base62
1000  62 = 16 remainder 8   '8'
  16  62 = 0 remainder 16   'G'
Result: "G8" (reversed)

Core Implementation

// Generate short URL
String encodeBase62(int num) {
    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
    while (num > 0) {
        sb.append(BASE62.charAt(num % 62));
        num /= 62;
    }
    return sb.reverse().toString();
}

// Handle duplicates
if (longToShort.containsKey(longURL)) {
    return longToShort.get(longURL);
}

Scaling Architecture

  • Database: PostgreSQL with B-tree index on shortURL (primary key)
  • Caching: Redis for top 20% of URLs (handle 80% of traffic)
  • Read Replicas: For 10:1 read/write ratio, use 10 read replicas
  • CDN: CloudFront for caching 301 redirects at edge locations
  • Sharding: Range-based on counter (0-1B, 1B-2B, etc.)

Database Schema

Table: urls
+------------+-------------------+
| short_url  | VARCHAR(10) PK    |
| long_url   | VARCHAR(2048)     |
| user_id    | INT               |
| created_at | TIMESTAMP         |
| clicks     | INT DEFAULT 0     |
+------------+-------------------+

Indexes:
- PRIMARY KEY on short_url
- INDEX on long_url (duplicate detection)
- INDEX on user_id (user history)

Advanced Features

  • Custom Aliases: bit.ly/google (check availability first)
  • Expiration: TTL for temporary marketing links
  • Analytics: Track clicks, geography, referrers, devices
  • Rate Limiting: 10 requests/min per IP to prevent spam
  • Malware Scanning: Integrate Google Safe Browsing API

Real-World Examples

Bit.ly: Handles 10B+ clicks/month. Uses Redis for caching and PostgreSQL for persistence. Generates revenue from analytics dashboard ($100M+ valuation).

TinyURL: Started in 2002, stores 600M+ URLs. Simple design, no analytics. Monetized via ads.

Google (goo.gl): Shut down in 2019 but handled billions of links with automatic malware detection.

Interview Discussion Points

  • Auto-increment vs Random Hash: Auto-increment is predictable but simpler to shard. Random hash avoids collisions but requires checking DB.
  • Handling Celebrity URLs: If Elon Musk tweets a link to 100M followers, use CDN + Redis to avoid database overload.
  • Global Distribution: Deploy in multiple regions (US-East, US-West, EU, Asia) and route users to nearest.
  • Security: Prevent phishing by scanning links before storing.

Best Practices

  • Use bidirectional mapping (Map and Map)
  • Implement exponential backoff for retries on collision
  • Log all shortening requests for analytics
  • Use 301 (permanent) vs 302 (temporary) redirects appropriately
  • Monitor cache hit ratio (aim for >90%)

Time Complexity

  • Generate: O(log n) for Base62 encoding, O(1) for HashMap insert
  • Lookup: O(1) for HashMap lookup
  • Space: O(n) where n = number of URLs

Related Problems

Master URL shortener to ace: Pastebin (same ID generation), Instagram photo IDs, Twitter Snowflake IDs, and any system requiring unique short identifiers.
